text: Step 7: Understand what constitutes statistical significance in your data. For groups with over 100 participants, a difference of five points or more is significant. For groups of 50 to 99, the difference must be 10 points, and for groups smaller than 50, it needs to be 15 points. This scale adjusts based on group size, as smaller groups can cause more significant shifts in data.
Step 8: Check the right side of your screen to see the "Who Responded" section, which displays your response rate, response count, and head count.

text: Step 9: Evaluate whether your survey's response rate is adequate. A response rate above 75% is generally considered good and statistically representative of your organization's population.
Step 1: Access the report to gauge your baseline performance, ensuring it meets at least the minimum N5 criteria. From here, begin building out various modules to further analyze your data.

Step 2: Identify the most favorable items within your report. These items display as percentages, showcasing areas of strength in either favorable, neutral, or unfavorable terms. Utilizing this information can provide a clear view of your overall strengths.
Step 3: Locate the most unfavorable items listed in your report. These represent key opportunities for improvement. Look for the three dots located in the top right corner of this section.
